headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Says Trump Will Seek to Remove Fluoride From Drinking Water
abstract: Donald J. Trump has said he would give Mr. Kennedy, a former rival who has long promoted unproven medical theories, a prominent health role if he wins.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said Saturday that among the first acts of a second Trump administration would be to “advise all U.S. water systems to remove fluoride from public water,” a stunning potential reversal of what is widely considered one of the most important public health interventions of the past century.
snippet: Donald J. Trump has said he would give Mr. Kennedy, a former rival who has long promoted unproven medical theories, a prominent health role if he wins.

headline: Kamala Harris Joins ‘S.N.L.’ for a Pep Talk With Maya Rudolph
abstract: Appearing in a mirror opposite her longtime impersonator, the vice president gave a little positive encouragement to her comedic reflection.
lead_paragraph: Election 2024 live updates: Follow our coverage of Trump and Harris on Election Day.
snippet: Appearing in a mirror opposite her longtime impersonator, the vice president gave a little positive encouragement to her comedic reflection.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 3, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Oct. 20 about Hugh Grant misstated the profession of Tinglan Hong, the mother of two of Grant’s children. She is not an actress.
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 3, 2024.

headline: At Women’s March in Washington, Hope That They Will Hold Off Trump
abstract: Thousands of women rallied in the capital and across the country for a Kamala Harris presidency — and to proclaim their resistance to Republican aims to restrict women’s reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight years after the first Women’s March in Washington demonstrated a furious backlash to the election of Donald J. Trump, thousands of women gathered again in the capital and across the country on Saturday, this time with the hope that Vice President Kamala Harris would triumph at the polls and prevent his return to the White House.
snippet: Thousands of women rallied in the capital and across the country for a Kamala Harris presidency — and to proclaim their resistance to Republican aims to restrict women’s reproductive rights.

headline: Sikh Activists See It as Freedom. India Calls It Terrorism.
abstract: Canadian and U.S. accusations of assassination plots have drawn attention to the Sikh separatist movement, which India calls a source of organized crime.
lead_paragraph: In the months since Canada and the United States accused India of carrying out assassination plots against Sikh separatist leaders on North American soil, a lingering question has hung over the accusations: Why would the Indian government take such a risk?
snippet: Canadian and U.S. accusations of assassination plots have drawn attention to the Sikh separatist movement, which India calls a source of organized crime.

headline: An ‘Interview’ With a Dead Luminary Exposes the Pitfalls of A.I.
abstract: A radio station in Poland fired its on-air talent and brought in A.I.-generated presenters. An outcry over a purported chat with a Nobel laureate quickly ended that experiment.
lead_paragraph: When a state-funded Polish radio station canceled a weekly show featuring interviews with theater directors and writers, the host of the program went quietly, resigned to media industry realities of cost-cutting and shifting tastes away from highbrow culture.
snippet: A radio station in Poland fired its on-air talent and brought in A.I.-generated presenters. An outcry over a purported chat with a Nobel laureate quickly ended that experiment.

headline: After Spain’s Floods, a Surge of Volunteers, and of Rage
abstract: As the country reels from a flood that has left at least 214 people dead, thousands have flocked to devastated areas to help. Anger toward public officials is growing.
lead_paragraph: They came by bus, by tractor or on foot. They waded through mud hoping to help clean up neighborhoods washed away by floodwaters that have killed at least 214 people.
snippet: As the country reels from a flood that has left at least 214 people dead, thousands have flocked to devastated areas to help. Anger toward public officials is growing.

headline: How One Lebanese Town Is Trying to Stay Out of the War Around It
abstract: While Lebanese are united against Israel’s onslaught, some in southern towns where Hezbollah does not hold sway say they feel caught between Israel’s firepower and Hezbollah’s fighters.
lead_paragraph: The patrol begins at dusk every night, as the thuds from nearby artillery echo over the distant hills in southern Lebanon. Some scouts settle into hidden perches on the outskirts of town, keeping close watch on the roads leading into it. Others hop on their motorcycles and roam the streets, alerting the police to any suspicious cars or strangers.
snippet: While Lebanese are united against Israel’s onslaught, some in southern towns where Hezbollah does not hold sway say they feel caught between Israel’s firepower and Hezbollah’s fighters.

headline: Quote of the Day: War Payments Have Russians Rolling in Cash
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “There is the spirit of a party out there. Now they have a car, they can drink and eat, it is a whole new life for them.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 3, 2024.

headline: Trump Laughs as Supporter Yells That Harris ‘Worked on the Corner’
abstract: “This place is amazing,” Donald Trump said after a supporter shouted the crude comment at a rally. A quick clarification followed: “Just remember, it’s other people saying it. It’s not me.”
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump faces a deficit with women in polls, he has spent some of the final days of his campaign defending himself from accusations of misogyny.
snippet: “This place is amazing,” Donald Trump said after a supporter shouted the crude comment at a rally. A quick clarification followed: “Just remember, it’s other people saying it. It’s not me.”

headline: Our 61 Focus Groups Make Me Think Trump Has a Good Chance of Winning
abstract: What we learned from interviewing nearly 700 Americans over almost three years.
lead_paragraph: After 61 focus groups for New York Times Opinion, listening to voters on the Biden presidency, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, and holding sessions with police officers, teachers, “Yellowstone” fans, young women, Black men, transgender people, tweens, 80-somethings and many others — what did we learn from it all?
snippet: What we learned from interviewing nearly 700 Americans over almost three years.

headline: A Second Trump Term? Three Conservative Columnists Unpack What Could Happen.
abstract: What will happen after Tuesday to Trumpism and the G.O.P. if Donald Trump wins — or loses?
lead_paragraph: Ross Douthat: Bret, David, I’ve been given a rare opportunity by an obliging genie: I get to describe to our past selves in the autumn of 2016 — when we were all sure Donald Trump would lose in a landslide — what the Republican Party and conservatism look like eight years in the future. Here’s what I’m going to tell them.
snippet: What will happen after Tuesday to Trumpism and the G.O.P. if Donald Trump wins — or loses?

headline: There’s Something Very Different About Harris vs. Trump
abstract: There’s something very different about Harris vs. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Imagine telling yourself, in 2012, that just three presidential elections into the future Barack Obama, Dick Cheney, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Alberto Gonzales, Barbara Lee and Elizabeth Warren would be endorsing the same candidate. Such is the strange breadth of Kamala Harris’s coalition: a popular front united not by shared policy goals but by a shared defense of American institutions.
snippet: There’s something very different about Harris vs. Trump.

headline: Live From New York, It’s Kamala Harris on ‘SNL’
abstract: The vice president made a brief appearance on “Saturday Night Live” this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Heading into a new “Saturday Night Live” hosted by the frequent guest John Mulaney on the last weekend before the presidential election, viewers were prepared for surprises. And they surely got one: a cameo appearance from Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia.
snippet: The vice president made a brief appearance on “Saturday Night Live” this weekend.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: At Least 11 Injured as Tornadoes Strike Oklahoma City
abstract: Severe weather swept through eastern Oklahoma early on Sunday, including at least six tornadoes that touched down, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: A dangerous line of storms swept through Oklahoma early on Sunday, bringing damaging winds and at least six tornadoes that tore through communities in and near the state capital, the authorities said.
snippet: Severe weather swept through eastern Oklahoma early on Sunday, including at least six tornadoes that touched down, the National Weather Service said.

headline: A Shirt With a Choke Hold on the Political Moment
abstract: The tie-front shirts serve as a reminder that no matter how far women have come, it’s not nearly as far as they think.
lead_paragraph: Recently the designer Ulla Johnson was thinking about what she would wear to vote on Tuesday, what would convey how seriously she took the stakes in this election. She was thinking, she said, about wearing a bow-tie blouse — maybe the crisp lemon yellow cut from her latest collection, tied with a flourish on the side of the neck. She was seeing the style of top more and more, she said, ever since Vice President Kamala Harris wore them at the Democratic National Convention.
snippet: The tie-front shirts serve as a reminder that no matter how far women have come, it’s not nearly as far as they think.

headline: The Daily Beast Tries to Claw Its Way Back to Relevance
abstract: Can Joanna Coles and Ben Sherwood revive the once-buzzy news site and reclaim their perches atop the New York media world? Their own staff isn’t sure.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny morning in early October, Joanna Coles, clad in a stylish tomato-red coat, and Ben Sherwood, dressed more demurely in a corduroy jacket, convened at their regular breakfast spot, the no-frills Star on 18 diner on Manhattan’s Far West Side.
snippet: Can Joanna Coles and Ben Sherwood revive the once-buzzy news site and reclaim their perches atop the New York media world? Their own staff isn’t sure.

headline: ‘I Made My Last Trip Down the Building’s Worn Marble Stairs ’
abstract: A surprise on moving day in Brooklyn, bird song in Bryant Park and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:
snippet: A surprise on moving day in Brooklyn, bird song in Bryant Park and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

headline: How a 178-Year-Old Magazine Stays Relevant, One Instagram Post at a Time
abstract: Stellene Volandes has brought new life to Town & Country, with snappy cover lines and an active social media presence. Could she be the next Anna Wintour?
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday morning in early October, Stellene Volandes, the editor in chief of Town & Country, sat around a conference table on the 19th floor in the Hearst Tower with three senior editors. They were intensely debating cover lines for the print magazine’s philanthropy issue, coming out in November with multiple cover subjects, including the actress Mariska Hargitay and the former football player Michael Strahan.
snippet: Stellene Volandes has brought new life to Town & Country, with snappy cover lines and an active social media presence. Could she be the next Anna Wintour?

headline: As Election Day Nears, Yard Signs Disappear
abstract: Modern technology including doorbell cameras and tiny tracking devices have turned the tables on sign stealers.
lead_paragraph: Mere hours after putting up several campaign signs along a road in Readington, N.J., Vincent Panico, got a ping on his phone.
snippet: Modern technology including doorbell cameras and tiny tracking devices have turned the tables on sign stealers.

headline: Where’s Johnny? The Biography of a TV Host Whose Life Was a Closed Book.
abstract: Johnny Carson dominated late-night television for decades, but closely guarded his privacy. Bill Zehme’s biography, “Carson the Magnificent,” tries to break through.
lead_paragraph: Maybe late-night TV shouldn’t be called “late-night TV” anymore, with so many viewers consuming it in clips the morning after, on their phones. Yet the genre’s hallmarks — the avuncular host, the sidekick, the band, the monologue, the desk, the guests — linger. Most were stamped on America’s consciousness by Johnny Carson.
snippet: Johnny Carson dominated late-night television for decades, but closely guarded his privacy. Bill Zehme’s biography, “Carson the Magnificent,” tries to break through.

headline: A Meal So Good, Politicians Leave Their Partisanship at the Door
abstract: The Inn at Little Washington, just over an hour away from D.C., is neutral ground for celebrities, foodies and politicians — regardless of party affiliation.
lead_paragraph: Not every small town in America is accustomed to a regular stream of black S.U.V.s, secret service agents and the thrum of helicopters. But for Washington, Va., with a population of fewer than 100 people, it’s a regular part of life. The village, just over an hour from a more famous Washington — Washington, D.C. — is home to the Inn at Little Washington, a restaurant and hotel that in more than 40 years of existence has hosted presidents and first ladies, Supreme Court justices and senators, and maybe even your aunt who drove in from Pittsburgh just for dinner.
snippet: The Inn at Little Washington, just over an hour away from D.C., is neutral ground for celebrities, foodies and politicians — regardless of party affiliation.

headline: Bookstores Are Setting Up Readers on ‘Blind Dates’ With Books
abstract: Bookstores say customers love “Blind Date With a Book,” which masks a book’s real cover and lets readers discover what’s inside.
lead_paragraph: Never judge a book by its cover — even if the cover doesn’t say much at all.
snippet: Bookstores say customers love “Blind Date With a Book,” which masks a book’s real cover and lets readers discover what’s inside.

headline: Tired? Here’s How to Know if You’re Sleep Deprived.
abstract: The time change can leave you yawning the next day. But for many Americans, sleep deprivation is a year-round problem.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to change the clocks again, and getting out of bed may feel harder than usual: Research has shown the sudden shift can be disruptive to sleep.
snippet: The time change can leave you yawning the next day. But for many Americans, sleep deprivation is a year-round problem.

headline: How Four Posts on Instagram Destroyed Her Life
abstract: On Oct. 7, an Israeli college student opened her phone. What she did next landed her in prison.
lead_paragraph: “The police are looking for you,” her father said.
snippet: On Oct. 7, an Israeli college student opened her phone. What she did next landed her in prison.

headline: How ‘Yellowstone’ Captured America
abstract: As the wildly popular TV western prepares to air its final episodes, we look at four ways it seized the country’s attention.
lead_paragraph: When the television series “Yellowstone” began in 2018, it was with a chip on its shoulder. HBO had passed on the show, pitched by its writer-director-executive producer Taylor Sheridan as “The Godfather” on horseback, for not quite fitting its prestige-oriented lineup. It was picked up instead by the fledgling network Paramount, which greenlit 10 episodes, to be broadcast on a rebranded version of Spike TV.
snippet: As the wildly popular TV western prepares to air its final episodes, we look at four ways it seized the country’s attention.

headline: Don’t Make Kelly Reilly Go Beth Dutton on You
abstract: Reilly turned her “Yellowstone” character, Beth, into a folk hero. As the show prepares to end, at least for now, “I’m very happy to let her disappear,” she said.
lead_paragraph: If Beth Dutton were Kelly Reilly’s friend, if she were sitting here, in the garden of a SoHo hotel, Reilly would worry. She would urge Beth to stop smoking, to drink less, to give therapy a try.
snippet: Reilly turned her “Yellowstone” character, Beth, into a folk hero. As the show prepares to end, at least for now, “I’m very happy to let her disappear,” she said.

headline: A French Veterinary Psychiatrist Puts Cats on the Couch
abstract: In “The Interpretation of Cats,” Claude Béata helps explain the inscrutable behavior of our feline companions.
lead_paragraph: Even Dog People must admit that cats are having a moment. In a year where Senator JD Vance’s comment about “childless cat ladies” touched off a political firestorm, and a New York magazine article called “Is My Cat a Prisoner?” positioned our pets as windows on our souls (or lack thereof), a book by a jovial Parisian veterinary psychiatrist has steadily climbed the French best-seller lists. Just translated and published in the United States, Claude Béata’s “The Interpretation of Cats” puts cats on the couch — as well as their human companions.
snippet: In “The Interpretation of Cats,” Claude Béata helps explain the inscrutable behavior of our feline companions.

headline: Trump Promises to Bring About a New Era of Christian Power
abstract: The Republican presidential nominee has pledged enhanced access to the White House. “It will be directly into the Oval Office — and me.”
lead_paragraph: As voters head to the polls on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump’s ambitions for America’s future are almost impossible to miss. He has sworn an era of “retribution” for his enemies. Vowed to deport millions of immigrants. Fueled concerns about rising fascism.
snippet: The Republican presidential nominee has pledged enhanced access to the White House. “It will be directly into the Oval Office — and me.”

headline: In an Internment Camp, All They Had Was Baseball. A New Generation Is Back to Play.
abstract: As Shohei Ohtani played in the World Series, Japanese American ballplayers gathered in Manzanar for the first baseball games in the internment camp since World War II.
lead_paragraph: First, the tumbleweeds were cleared. Then, an archaeological dig found the posts for the backstop and the bases. Finally, old black-and-white photographs unearthed in an archive in Los Angeles were examined to make sure everything was reconstructed exactly as it had been.
snippet: As Shohei Ohtani played in the World Series, Japanese American ballplayers gathered in Manzanar for the first baseball games in the internment camp since World War II.

headline: How Elon Musk’s Own Account Dominates X
abstract: The billionaire has effectively become the star of his social media platform, transforming X into a reflection of his personal views before the election.
lead_paragraph: Days ahead of the presidential election, Elon Musk’s centrality to his social media platform, X, has become more pronounced.
snippet: The billionaire has effectively become the star of his social media platform, transforming X into a reflection of his personal views before the election.

headline: This Overlooked Michigan County Gets the Political Spotlight Every 4 Years
abstract: As Election Day nears, both campaigns have poured time and energy into Saginaw County, which voted for Donald Trump in 2016 and Joe Biden in 2020.
lead_paragraph: There is a pervasive sense in and around Saginaw, Mich., of being overlooked, even forgotten, by both industry and government.
snippet: As Election Day nears, both campaigns have poured time and energy into Saginaw County, which voted for Donald Trump in 2016 and Joe Biden in 2020.

headline: Three Questions About Election Results
abstract: Why might election results take so long? And how can a candidate lose an early lead? Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, has some answers.
lead_paragraph: Why might election results take so long? And how can a candidate lose an early lead? Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, has some answers.
snippet: Why might election results take so long? And how can a candidate lose an early lead? Nick Corasaniti, a New York Times reporter covering voting, has some answers.

headline: Trump’s Closing Argument: Lies, Distortions and Inaccuracies
abstract: Beyoncé, whales, voting and immigration: For Mr. Trump, no topic is too insignificant or too important when it comes to making misleading or inaccurate statements.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, in the closing days of the 2024 election, continues to be a font of exaggerations, misleading claims and outright lies.
snippet: Beyoncé, whales, voting and immigration: For Mr. Trump, no topic is too insignificant or too important when it comes to making misleading or inaccurate statements.

headline: Trump or Harris? For Ukraine, Two Very Different Futures Loom.
abstract: The presidential candidates have expressed starkly contrasting visions for America’s role in the war, as well as the NATO alliance that serves as a shield against Russian aggression.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian military is losing ground in eastern Ukraine at the fastest pace in years. An influx of several thousand North Korean soldiers to Russia has added an unpredictable new dimension to the most savage war in Europe in generations.
snippet: The presidential candidates have expressed starkly contrasting visions for America’s role in the war, as well as the NATO alliance that serves as a shield against Russian aggression.

headline: Trump’s Wild Claims, Conspiracies and Falsehoods Redefine Presidential Bounds
abstract: Throughout his life, Donald J. Trump has bent the truth to serve his needs, never more so than on the campaign trail to win back the White House.
lead_paragraph: It took just two minutes for former President Donald J. Trump to utter his first lie of the evening, claiming once again that the 2020 election had been stolen.
snippet: Throughout his life, Donald J. Trump has bent the truth to serve his needs, never more so than on the campaign trail to win back the White House.

headline: In a Perfect World, We’d Eliminate Expense Reports. We’re Getting Closer.
abstract: We hate them. The companies that build expense management software know that we hate them. They would like things to be different.
lead_paragraph: Once you file a few expense reports at work, a couple of things become clear.
snippet: We hate them. The companies that build expense management software know that we hate them. They would like things to be different.

headline: Harris and Trump Battle to the Wire in Swing States, Times/Siena Polls Find
abstract: Donald J. Trump has improved his standing in Pennsylvania even as late-deciding voters appear to be breaking for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: The presidential race appears to be hurtling toward a photo finish, with the final set of polls by The New York Times and Siena College finding Vice President Kamala Harris showing new strength in North Carolina and Georgia as former President Donald J. Trump erases her lead in Pennsylvania and maintains his advantage in Arizona.
snippet: Donald J. Trump has improved his standing in Pennsylvania even as late-deciding voters appear to be breaking for Kamala Harris.

headline: In Louisville, Relief and Regret After Ex-Officer’s Conviction in Breonna Taylor Case
abstract: After a jury found that a former police detective used excessive force in the 2020 raid that killed Ms. Taylor, residents expressed both hope for police reform and reservations about the verdict.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, thousands of demonstrators would squeeze into Jefferson Square Park in downtown Louisville, Ky., to remember Breonna Taylor. They marched, they chanted, they gathered for vigils. Police officers broke up crowds with flash bang grenades. It was the epicenter for racial justice protests in the city.
snippet: After a jury found that a former police detective used excessive force in the 2020 raid that killed Ms. Taylor, residents expressed both hope for police reform and reservations about the verdict.

headline: Harris Appeals to Latino Pride, and Anger at Trump, in Final Push
abstract: Kamala Harris is hoping that backlash to the bigotry at the Madison Square Garden rally will blunt Donald Trump’s appeal with a critical group of voters.
lead_paragraph: Walter Mendoza, 30, was exasperated with his mother, Ana, as they walked in to Supremo Foods in Allentown, Pa., last week.
snippet: Kamala Harris is hoping that backlash to the bigotry at the Madison Square Garden rally will blunt Donald Trump’s appeal with a critical group of voters.

headline: Some Surprises in Last Battleground Polls, but Still a Deadlock
abstract: A rise for Kamala Harris in the Sun Belt, and a dip in the Northern swing states.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump stayed deadlocked to the finish in the final New York Times/Siena College polls of the 2024 presidential election, though there may be a hint she has ticked up in the final stretch.
snippet: A rise for Kamala Harris in the Sun Belt, and a dip in the Northern swing states.

headline: But He Digresses: Trump’s Strangest Detours Down the Stretch
abstract: In the campaign’s homestretch, whether because of fatigue or something else entirely, Donald Trump seems to be indulging in surreal, sometimes vulgar, verbal detours.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has long sprinkled his speeches with baffling digressions — weighing the relative merits of death by electrocution or shark attack, or comparing immigrants to the “late, great Hannibal Lecter” — sometimes even turning them into recurring bits.
snippet: In the campaign’s homestretch, whether because of fatigue or something else entirely, Donald Trump seems to be indulging in surreal, sometimes vulgar, verbal detours.

headline: Free Your Mind. The Election Will Follow.
abstract: It is essential to carve out space for other things
lead_paragraph: In these edgy and ominous days, anyone suggesting that it might be wise to pay a bit less attention to the dramas of presidential politics is likely to receive a tongue lashing. Even to contemplate the idea exudes an unrealistic escapism; maybe some can afford not to care too much about the outcome, but surely most can’t. Besides, it just feels impossible: We’re transfixed — whichever candidate you intend to vote for — by the potential for catastrophe, like rabbits caught in headlights.
snippet: It is essential to carve out space for other things

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,234
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 4, 2024.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 512
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Nov. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Nov. 4, 2024.

headline: Women Are Dying in Post-Roe America, and Your Vote Matters
abstract: Access to basic women’s health care is under threat on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Over 20 years ago, I had an experience that will be familiar to many women. I had a series of miscarriages, including one for which I needed a medical procedure to protect me from infection — which is to say, to protect me from possible death.
snippet: Access to basic women’s health care is under threat on Election Day.

headline: Want to Make Sense of the Chaos on Election Night? Here Are the House Races I’m Watching.
abstract: Key districts will give us clues for how the election is going. They may also answer some of the big demographic questions looming over U.S. politics.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential race comes down to the wire, so too does the race for the U.S. House of Representatives. Democrats have a roughly 50-50 shot at reclaiming control of the chamber; to do so, they need to win only four more seats than they currently hold (214, including a couple of current vacancies in safely Democratic districts).
snippet: Key districts will give us clues for how the election is going. They may also answer some of the big demographic questions looming over U.S. politics.

headline: Where Do Nikki Haley Voters Turn?
abstract: The Haley voters who cast ballots for Harris are a new kind of conservative voter.
lead_paragraph: For Kamala Harris to win, are there enough Nikki Haley voters and other disaffected Republicans who will vote for her or sit this one out?
snippet: The Haley voters who cast ballots for Harris are a new kind of conservative voter.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Their Son’s Death Was Devastating. Then Politics Made It Worse.’
abstract: After Aiden Clark was killed in a school bus accident in Springfield, Ohio, his death inspired conspiracy theories, campaign lies and anti-immigrant hate. Now his family is the latest target.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains racist language.
snippet: After Aiden Clark was killed in a school bus accident in Springfield, Ohio, his death inspired conspiracy theories, campaign lies and anti-immigrant hate. Now his family is the latest target.

headline: How Power Shoulders Tell a Story of This Campaign
abstract: Padded shoulders originated in military and hunting attire. But they’ve come to communicate so much more, creating a silhouette embraced by both candidates.
lead_paragraph: This is an installment of Visual Studies, a series that explores how images move through and shape culture.
snippet: Padded shoulders originated in military and hunting attire. But they’ve come to communicate so much more, creating a silhouette embraced by both candidates.

headline: There Will Always Be a Trump. That’s Only Part of the Problem.
abstract: The question is how to keep him — and those like him — in check.
lead_paragraph: Because we forget history, we forget that the American experiment cannot succeed without constant, courageous leadership. Our nation is not inherently good, and our high ideals are often eclipsed by our baser nature. This has been true since our founding, and it is true now.
snippet: The question is how to keep him — and those like him — in check.

headline: Thousands of Children in Gaza Get 2nd Dose of Polio Vaccine
abstract: Aid agencies said that children in some areas of northern Gaza where Israel is mounting an offensive against Hamas will miss the doses, compromising the effectiveness of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 94,000 children in Gaza City received a second dose of polio vaccine this weekend in an effort that was delayed by intense Israeli bombardment and mass evacuation orders in northern Gaza, the Gazan health ministry said.
snippet: Aid agencies said that children in some areas of northern Gaza where Israel is mounting an offensive against Hamas will miss the doses, compromising the effectiveness of the campaign.

headline: Daniel Romanchuk’s Pre-Marathon Routine Includes Sandpaper
abstract: There is no dedicated wheelchair repair shop at the New York City Marathon, so racers and their coaches come prepared with an array of tools to allow them to make fixes on the fly.
lead_paragraph: Many of the 50,000 entrants in the New York City Marathon have pre-race routines — carbo-loading, plenty of liquids and so on — but only a few of these routines include wrenches, Allen keys and sandpaper.
snippet: There is no dedicated wheelchair repair shop at the New York City Marathon, so racers and their coaches come prepared with an array of tools to allow them to make fixes on the fly.

headline: 20/20 Foresight
abstract: We’re covering the strategic risks that Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are taking.
lead_paragraph: Once an election is over, hindsight can make the winner’s strategy look perfect and the loser’s seem doomed. As my colleague Jonathan Swan said recently on “The Daily”: “The winning campaign, everything they did was genius, and then the losing campaign are just a bunch of idiots. And the truth is that neither is necessarily true.”
snippet: We’re covering the strategic risks that Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are taking.

headline: Which Celebrities Are Running the New York City Marathon?
abstract: The actors Randall Park, Jennifer Connelly and Claire Holt have signed up, as have an NBC News correspondent and a beauty influencer.
lead_paragraph: Among those running the marathon are people who, in addition to being talented and famous, are apparently in great shape, too.
snippet: The actors Randall Park, Jennifer Connelly and Claire Holt have signed up, as have an NBC News correspondent and a beauty influencer.

headline: The Emptiness of the Universe Gives Our Lives Meaning
abstract: Most of the universe is made of nothingness. That realization should make us feel empowered, not frightened.
lead_paragraph: Nietzsche was wrong: When you gaze long enough into the abyss, the abyss does not gaze back into you. Instead, the void remains silent, relentless and frightening in its enormity. But when we peer into the infinite blackness that defines the expanse of our universe, we are offered a choice. We can recoil in fear and disregard our humanity in the face of sheer cosmic dread. Or we can transform the shadows of the cosmos into a light that illuminates the uniqueness of everything we know here on Earth.
snippet: Most of the universe is made of nothingness. That realization should make us feel empowered, not frightened.

headline: Romanchuk and Scaroni Win Wheelchair Races in Sweep for Americans
abstract: Romanchuk used a late sprint to win his third New York City Marathon, while Scaroni led from start to finish.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Romanchuk won the men’s wheelchair division in the New York City Marathon for the third time, sprinting away from the field in Central Park for a 5-second victory, while his fellow American Susannah Scaroni dominated the women’s field from start to finish, her second victory in the race.
snippet: Romanchuk used a late sprint to win his third New York City Marathon, while Scaroni led from start to finish.

headline: Say Cheese Enchiladas
abstract: “Enchiladas are warm hugs, enveloped in tortillas and blanketed in sauce,” Bryan Washington wrote. Truer words? Never spoken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A couple of years ago, Bryan Washington wrote a moving piece for The New York Times Magazine about cheese enchiladas (above) that reminded me of a terrific few days I once spent in Houston researching their deliciousness.
snippet: “Enchiladas are warm hugs, enveloped in tortillas and blanketed in sauce,” Bryan Washington wrote. Truer words? Never spoken.

headline: Business Leaders and the Election
abstract: Readers call on business leaders to help save our democracy. Also: After the voting; swing states; Holocaust legacy; defending corporate D.E.I.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Readers call on business leaders to help save our democracy. Also: After the voting; swing states; Holocaust legacy; defending corporate D.E.I.

headline: What’s Powering 3 Generations of Runners? Family, Grit and Sandwiches.
abstract: The New York City Marathon is a family tradition for the Villavicencios.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Rodrigo Villavicencio is running his 20th New York City Marathon. His son, James, is running his ninth. And for the first time, his grandson Justin is joining them.
snippet: The New York City Marathon is a family tradition for the Villavicencios.

headline: What’s the Secret to a Good Water Handoff at the N.Y.C. Marathon?
abstract: Jeffrey Laperuta, 75, knows. He has volunteered at the Mile 3 fluid station of the New York City Marathon every year since 1984.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of transferring water or Gatorade into the hands of runners, according to a New York City Marathon volunteer veteran: Don’t step out into the road.
snippet: Jeffrey Laperuta, 75, knows. He has volunteered at the Mile 3 fluid station of the New York City Marathon every year since 1984.

headline: Trump, in Increasingly Dark and Dour Tones, Says He ‘Shouldn’t Have Left’ the White House
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who sought to overturn his loss of the 2020 election, also suggested that he didn’t mind if reporters were shot.
lead_paragraph: With two days left in his third presidential campaign, former President Donald J. Trump told supporters at a Pennsylvania rally on Sunday that he “shouldn’t have left” the White House at the end of his term, escalated his unfounded claims of voter fraud and said “I don’t mind” if reporters are shot at.
snippet: Donald J. Trump, who sought to overturn his loss of the 2020 election, also suggested that he didn’t mind if reporters were shot.

headline: James O’Keefe Recruits Election Workers to Secretly Record at the Polls
abstract: Mr. O’Keefe has sought volunteers willing to wear hidden cameras and hunt for voting problems. Dozens of election judges and poll monitors responded, records show.
lead_paragraph: James O’Keefe, the conservative influencer who founded and formerly led Project Veritas, has assembled a corps of election workers and poll monitors planning to secretly film voting and ballot counting in states across the country.
snippet: Mr. O’Keefe has sought volunteers willing to wear hidden cameras and hunt for voting problems. Dozens of election judges and poll monitors responded, records show.

headline: He’s Running the N.Y.C. Marathon as Part of His Recovery From Addiction
abstract: Travis Friese is running on a team organized by Odyssey House, a residential treatment program.
lead_paragraph: His first time in rehab, Travis Friese thought he could just learn to use drugs less frequently, and in that way avoid the negative effects of addiction.
snippet: Travis Friese is running on a team organized by Odyssey House, a residential treatment program.

headline: With Oil Prices Weak, OPEC Plus Postpones Increases Again
abstract: Saudi Arabia, which leads the group, appears wary of unsettling markets just before the U.S. presidential election on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and seven other oil-producing countries said on Sunday that they would postpone plans to gradually increase oil output until the end of December, according to a news release posted on the website of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
snippet: Saudi Arabia, which leads the group, appears wary of unsettling markets just before the U.S. presidential election on Tuesday.

headline: Weary, Troubled and Nervous: Americans Flood the Early Vote
abstract: Nearly 75 million people have cast early ballots, making their voices heard amid worry about the process, the outcome and democracy itself.
lead_paragraph: An anxious America, weary from a vitriolic campaign season and worried about the state of the nation’s democracy, is voting with determination, with roughly 75 million people having cast ballots in the early voting period.
snippet: Nearly 75 million people have cast early ballots, making their voices heard amid worry about the process, the outcome and democracy itself.

headline: Georgia Judge Rejects Republican Lawsuit to Block Hand-Returned Mail Ballots
abstract: The lawsuit targeted Fulton County, a Democratic stronghold, seeking to stop it from opening election offices over the weekend to receive absentee ballots in person.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia judge on Saturday rejected a Republican lawsuit aimed at blocking counties from opening election offices over the weekend to let voters return their absentee ballots in person.
snippet: The lawsuit targeted Fulton County, a Democratic stronghold, seeking to stop it from opening election offices over the weekend to receive absentee ballots in person.

headline: What One Tossup District Says About the Trump-Harris Battle for the Suburbs
abstract: Representative David Schweikert, a vulnerable Republican, is fighting for his political life in suburban Arizona, where the sprint to win over a crucial bloc of voters is coming down to the wire.
lead_paragraph: Knocking on doors in Phoenix and Scottsdale in the election’s frantic final days, canvassers working on behalf of the Democratic candidate for the U.S. House were greeted by reactions from across the political spectrum.
snippet: Representative David Schweikert, a vulnerable Republican, is fighting for his political life in suburban Arizona, where the sprint to win over a crucial bloc of voters is coming down to the wire.

headline: Joey Jay, First Little Leaguer to Get to the Majors, Dies at 89
abstract: A pitcher who won 99 games in 13 seasons, he played for the Braves and the Reds. But when he retired, he never looked back.
lead_paragraph: Joey Jay, who in 1953 became the first former Little Leaguer to reach the major leagues and went on to win 99 games in 13 seasons pitching for the Milwaukee (later Atlanta) Braves and the Cincinnati Reds, died on Sept. 27 in Lutz, Fla. He was 89 and had lived in the Tampa Bay area in his later years.
snippet: A pitcher who won 99 games in 13 seasons, he played for the Braves and the Reds. But when he retired, he never looked back.

headline: U.S. Confirms Reports That Iran Arrested an Iranian-American Citizen
abstract: Rights groups said that Reza Valizadeh, an Iranian-American journalist, was recently arrested in Iran, although the State Department did not confirm that he was the person detained.
lead_paragraph: The State Department confirmed that it was looking into reports that an Iranian-American citizen had been arrested in Iran. The news comes amid renewed tensions between Iran, which has long used Western detainees for leverage, and the United States, Israel’s biggest ally, following Israeli airstrikes on Iran last month.
snippet: Rights groups said that Reza Valizadeh, an Iranian-American journalist, was recently arrested in Iran, although the State Department did not confirm that he was the person detained.

headline: 9 Memorable Looks at the New York City Marathon
abstract: Form versus function can be debated another time as these marathoners made sure they looked good while they were running hard.
lead_paragraph: As the sun rose on Sunday, thousands of runners packed into Fort Wadsworth, a 226-acre park on the eastern shore of Staten Island, where the New York City Marathon was set to kick off.
snippet: Form versus function can be debated another time as these marathoners made sure they looked good while they were running hard.

headline: Entire City Police Force in Oklahoma Quits as 2 Council Members Also Resign
abstract: The reasons for the abrupt mass departures in the city of Geary, Okla., which has a population of just under 1,000, were unclear.
lead_paragraph: Three officers and the chief of a four-person police department in a small city in Oklahoma abruptly resigned on Thursday, as did two of its three City Council members, all with little explanation.
snippet: The reasons for the abrupt mass departures in the city of Geary, Okla., which has a population of just under 1,000, were unclear.

headline: Biden Wanted to Fix Immigration, but Leaves Behind a System That Is Still Broken
abstract: President Biden’s legacy will largely be limited to his success in lowering border crossings. But his approach has drawn criticism, and some of his actions have moved the problem deeper into the country.
lead_paragraph: President Biden had big ambitions for remaking America’s immigration system.
snippet: President Biden’s legacy will largely be limited to his success in lowering border crossings. But his approach has drawn criticism, and some of his actions have moved the problem deeper into the country.

headline: Abdi Nageeye and Sheila Chepkirui Win New York City Marathon
abstract: A riveting competition ended with one-on-one clashes in both the men’s and women’s races, and with three Kenyans on the women’s podium.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Chepkirui of Kenya was well aware of the esteemed company that she was keeping in the late stages of the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning.
snippet: A riveting competition ended with one-on-one clashes in both the men’s and women’s races, and with three Kenyans on the women’s podium.

headline: Crime Has Been a Big Talking Point. How Does It Look in Battleground States?
abstract: Even as violence crime rates fall, Republicans have sought to tie murders and drug overdoses to migrants. Here’s a rundown of crime rates in swing states.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump routinely raises the issue of crime on the campaign trail, saying that it is “through the roof” and that cities like Philadelphia are “ravaged by bloodshed.”
snippet: Even as violence crime rates fall, Republicans have sought to tie murders and drug overdoses to migrants. Here’s a rundown of crime rates in swing states.

headline: The New York City Marathon, in Photos
abstract: New York Times photographers captured scenes of today’s race across the city. Here are some of their photos.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 runners were taking part in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, making the 26.2 mile journey from Staten Island to Central Park. The weather was cooler than in recent years, allowing for perfect conditions.
snippet: New York Times photographers captured scenes of today’s race across the city. Here are some of their photos.

headline: Fiery Michigan Crash Kills 4 After Semi Truck Slams Into Stopped Traffic
abstract: Seventeen other people were injured in the crash, which happened Saturday night on a highway east of Lansing after traffic had been halted to allow for utility work.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed and 17 others, including children, were seriously injured after a semi truck crashed into vehicles stopped on a highway in Michigan on Saturday night, the authorities said.
snippet: Seventeen other people were injured in the crash, which happened Saturday night on a highway east of Lansing after traffic had been halted to allow for utility work.

headline: Monday Briefing: The Final Set of Times/Siena Election Polls
abstract: Plus, using generative A.I. to take a “decision holiday.”
lead_paragraph: There’s one more day until Election Day, and the final set of Times/Siena polls are in.
snippet: Plus, using generative A.I. to take a “decision holiday.”

headline: An ‘S.N.L.’ Sketch Gives Harvey Epstein His 15 Minutes of Fame
abstract: Mr. Epstein, a state assemblyman who is running for New York City Council, had no idea he would be the subject of a skit watched by millions.
lead_paragraph: When Harvey Epstein went to sleep on Saturday night, he was a low-profile New York State assemblyman. When he woke up on Sunday morning, he was something of an internet celebrity.
snippet: Mr. Epstein, a state assemblyman who is running for New York City Council, had no idea he would be the subject of a skit watched by millions.

headline: Trump Says He Thinks Julia Roberts Will Regret Ad Supporting Harris
abstract: Ms. Roberts narrated an ad suggesting that women could privately vote for Vice President Kamala Harris without letting their husbands know.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said Saturday morning that he thought the actress Julia Roberts would come to regret narrating an ad suggesting that women could privately vote for Vice President Kamala Harris while telling their husbands otherwise.
snippet: Ms. Roberts narrated an ad suggesting that women could privately vote for Vice President Kamala Harris without letting their husbands know.

headline: Trump Says He May Move Against Some Vaccinations and Fluoride in Water
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump expressed openness to proposals set forth by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic he has said would be allowed to “go wild on health.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he expected Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to have a “big role” in a second administration, and acknowledged the possibility that he could take action against two major public health successes — vaccines and the fluoridation of water — if he won the presidency.
snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump expressed openness to proposals set forth by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic he has said would be allowed to “go wild on health.”

headline: New Yorkers Celebrate the 53rd New York City Marathon
abstract: Hundreds of thousands turned out across New York City to cheer on marathon participants.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands turned out across New York City to cheer on marathon participants.
snippet: Hundreds of thousands turned out across New York City to cheer on marathon participants.

headline: What Polls Can Tell Us, Beyond the Horse Race
abstract: As the election dust prepares to settle, patterns are emerging that might provide valuable context in the weeks to come.
lead_paragraph: Put your phone down, and back slowly away from those election forecasts. In a presidential race that has remained stubbornly close for weeks, nothing short of a campaign-shattering seismic event is likely to budge the polls much in the next few days.
snippet: As the election dust prepares to settle, patterns are emerging that might provide valuable context in the weeks to come.

headline: Alan Rachins, ‘L.A. Law’ and ‘Dharma & Greg’ Actor, Dies at 82
abstract: He became recognizable as a performer whose specialty was difficult men, in both absurd comedies and tense dramas.
lead_paragraph: Alan Rachins, who delighted TV watchers by playing two very different kinds of histrionic middle-aged men in two hit shows, “L.A. Law” and “Dharma & Greg,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 82.
snippet: He became recognizable as a performer whose specialty was difficult men, in both absurd comedies and tense dramas.

headline: Obama Gives Tailored Pitch to Voters Wavering on Harris
abstract: Barack Obama’s laundry list for different constituencies hinted at what groups Democrats were focusing on in the final hours before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama, in a long and impassioned speech on the final day of early voting in Wisconsin, made a plea to voters to back Vice President Kamala Harris even if they disagree with her on a particular policy issue or have lost trust in Democratic politicians.
snippet: Barack Obama’s laundry list for different constituencies hinted at what groups Democrats were focusing on in the final hours before Election Day.

headline: Rainy-Day Reserves
abstract: Get into solving mode for this puzzle by Colin Adams.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
snippet: Get into solving mode for this puzzle by Colin Adams.

headline: Gretchen Whitmer Rallies Michigan Democrats as Election Day Nears
abstract: Ms. Whitmer won re-election as Michigan’s governor by 11 percentage points two years ago. Polls show a much closer race for president.
lead_paragraph: A campaign bus adorned with “BIG GRETCH SAYS GO VOTE” signage pulled into a labor union parking lot on Saturday as dozens of bundled-up Democrats prepared to knock on doors in East Lansing, Mich., a liberal stronghold in a closely divided state.
snippet: Ms. Whitmer won re-election as Michigan’s governor by 11 percentage points two years ago. Polls show a much closer race for president.

headline: Review: Seven Dancers, a Mosaic of Movement
abstract: Netta Yerushalmy’s “Movement” at N.Y.U. Skirball comes from a patchwork of sources: TikTok, television, marching band practice and more.
lead_paragraph: When a group of dancers gets together, they arrive with years of information stored in their bodies: layers upon layers of formal training and, like anyone else, of everyday experience just moving through the world.
snippet: Netta Yerushalmy’s “Movement” at N.Y.U. Skirball comes from a patchwork of sources: TikTok, television, marching band practice and more.

headline: Pro-West Leader Wins High-Stakes Vote in Former Soviet Republic
abstract: The president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”
lead_paragraph: The pro-Western president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday in a high-stakes runoff vote in the former Soviet republic against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”
snippet: The president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”

headline: California County to Pay $300,000 Over Butchering of Girl’s Goat
abstract: The girl and her family reached a settlement after accusing the Shasta County Sheriff’s Office of unlawfully seizing a pet goat that was sold and slaughtered.
lead_paragraph: A California county’s sheriff’s office agreed to pay $300,000 after it seized a 9-year-old girl’s pet goat, which was later slaughtered, according to court documents made public Friday.
snippet: The girl and her family reached a settlement after accusing the Shasta County Sheriff’s Office of unlawfully seizing a pet goat that was sold and slaughtered.
